subject: Gardening
title: Rethinking the Garden Ecosystem
description: A quick, practical guide to Rethinking the Garden Ecosystem.

hook.text: Knowing what plants can sense, communicate, and decide changes how you should think about your garden.

buildup.text: Every plant in your garden is sensing light direction, detecting neighbors, and signaling through root networks.

discovery.text: Companion planting works partly because plants chemically communicate and share resources underground.

twist.text: Monocultures fail because they strip away the communication networks that diverse plantings create naturally.

climax.text: A garden isn't a collection of silent objects. It's a chattering community of sensing, deciding organisms.

punchline.text: Your garden is talking. Now you know how to listen.

quiz.question: Why do monocultures tend to be more vulnerable than diverse plantings?
options: Single species use up all the water in the soil
They lack the communication networks and resource sharing that diverse plantings create
Monocultures attract fewer pollinators than mixed gardens
